iati-activity.title: MANAGEMENT OF PCBs
iati-activity.description: Minimizing environmental and health risks associated with Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) though strengthening technical and regulatory capacity for the environmentally sound management and disposal of PCBs in Kyrgyzstan.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

actual.comment: 1. Laboratory of the Ministry of Health was supported with additional reference materials and reagents for the completion of the laboratory tests of the PCB samples from 52 energy enterprises. The tests have been done and results were submitted to UNDP. The samples found to have high concentration of PCBs. For final reference confirmation, seven samples from seven provinces were submitted to an Internationally accredited laboratory in Kazakhstan - results are expected in October 2015. 2. National Electric Grid Company of Kyrgyzstan has adopted the Regulation for safe management and disposal of PCB equipment that were approved by the order of the Ministry of Energy and Industry as of September 10, 2014. Having adopted it, they have made internal inventory of their equipment and trained own staff across the country on safe management and handling of PCB equipment. 3. The equipment has been delivered and installed. Laboratory staff of the State Agency have been trained by the laboratory staff of the Ministry of Health, in accordance with the MoU signed between two governmental bodies on transfer of experience and skills. Now having these two laboratories operational and equipped to identify and confirm PCBs, the country has a unique advantage in terms of having in-house capacity for reference tests. 3.1. The laboratory of the Ministry of Health has participated in the international reference test program led by Australian company PTA. The laboratory has qualified 20%, however this activity has increased their experience and unskilled them in dealing with internationally certified standards and methodologies. The laboratory will further develop and improve their analytical methodology and run in the next round of the reference test programme of the PTA. 4. The Ministry of Energy and Industry, as a follow-up to the earlier approved regulations on safe management of PCBs, is now seeking for alternative options for secure storage and placement of identified PCBs in the te

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Number of new bacteriologically confirmed TB cases notified to national health authority 2. Number of TB cases (all forms, new and relapses) notified to national health authority 3. Number and percent of new smear positive sensitive TB cases that are successfully treated 4. Number of laboratory confirmed MDR/ XDR/RR-TB patients enrolled on second line anti-TB treatment (in both civil and penitentiary sectors) 5. Interim result: culture conversion of MDR-TB/XDR/RR cases at six months: MDR/XDR/RR-TB cases initiated on a second-line treatment who have a negative culture at the end of six months of treatment during the specified period of assessment 6. Number of MDR/XDR/RR-TB patients on treatment receiving patient support (food, hygiene packages, money allowances) for better adherence to treatment- includes inpatient and outpatient treatment 7. Number TB service staff trained in DR-TB management locally and number of nurses trained for provision of DR-TB treatment adherence counselling. 8. Number of MDR/XDR/RR-TB patients counselled and trained on DR-TB treatment during the inpatient treatment phase. 9. TB cases with result for drug susceptibility testing: TB cases with results for diagnostic DST for MDR-TB among those eligible for drug susceptible testing according to national policy

actual.comment:
1. The National TB data reports 1849 new bacteriologically confirmed TB cases, notified to the health authorities in 2014. Of them female represent 805 and male- 1044 cases. The civilian health sector contributes 1809 of them and the rest 40 cases relate to prisons. The good performance of indicator was contributed by such the GF funded resources , provided to the National TB program as TA, lab. reagents and consumables, training of the medical staff, and motivation payments on the basis of the performance based approach.
2. A total number of all TB cases, reported by NTP in 2014 was at 6390 against 5662 targeted. The absolute number consists of 1849 new bacteriologically confirmed, 2407 new smear negative,1624 extrapulmonary and 510 relapse cases. (3 619 cases- Male,female -2771). The civilian health sector contributed 6233 cases, and the rest 157 relate to prisons. The indicator of all TB cases notified was performed at 113 %. This good performance was contributed by such the GF funded resources, provided to the National TB program as TA, lab. reagents and consumables, training of the medical staff and the motivation payments on the basis of the performance based approach.
3. Of 1670 new smear positive TB cases, reported by NTP for Y2013, 1349 were assessed by NTP for outcomes. The rest 321 cases were either reconsidered for their TB diagnosis, or on the basis of their drug resistance profile were transferred to the DR-TB register (according to the new WHO definitions).Thus, the treatment success rate among the new smear positive cases, registered in 2013 was reported at 81,2% (1096 out of 1349). Prison health sector achieved 84,6 % (22 out of 26), civil sector - 81.2% (1074 out 1323). We highlight that for the first time of the grant, the results of the prison and civilian sectors were equal. Previously the prison sector used to demonstrate the significantly lower outcomes. The overall indicator was achieved at 97% 4. During the reporting perio
To be filled first quarter of 2016

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Regional knowledge networks for sustainable training capacity building established; and regional training materials harmonized; 2. Number of staff of border agencies, including dog handlers, received professional skills enhancement through training activities, special thematic courses and study tours.

baseline.comment: Poor border management by enforcement agencies; there is a lack of interagency and international cooperation and information exchange

target.comment: 1. At least 50 Uzbek law enforcement and border officers enhanced professional skills via training activities, study tours and experience exchange 2. At least 20training events are organized at national, intra/inter-agency levels 3. At least 10 Uzbek law enforcement and border officers are trained in interception of drugs and precursor chemicals 4. At least 4trainings are organized on combating trafficking in illicit drugs and chemical precursors; DPU training events and inter-agency & international cooperation supported 5. At least 5 meetings with partners are held 6. At least 1donor meeting is organized

actual.comment:
Output 1: 1.1. 77 Uzbek law enforcement and border officers enhanced professional skills via participation in training activities, study tours and experience exchange. 1.2. Uzbek beneficiaries participated in 3 national and 1 regional trainings, 2 STs and 2 Border Guards/Customs training institutions Consortia meetings.
Output 2: 2.1. 50 Uzbek law enforcement and border officers were trained in 2014. 2.2. 2 national training courses on ANACAPA were organized; Uzbek beneficiaries participated in 2 study tours and 1 regional meeting.
Output 3: 3.1. 7 meetings with partners were held in 2014; 3.2. 1 Donors’ meeting was organized in 2014.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.Percentage of adults and children with HIV known to be on treatment 12 months after initiation of antiretroviral therapy 2.Number of PLHIV reached with community care and support programs 3. Number and percentage of PWIDs reached by HIV preventive programmes 4. Number of PWID in prisons covered with HIV prevention programmes 5. Number of PWIDs reached by methadone substitution therapy 6. Percentage of individuals receiving OST who received treatment for at least six months 7. Number and percentage of sex workers reached by prevention programs 8. Number and percentage of MSM reached by prevention programmes 9. Number and percentage of adults and children with advanced HIV infection (currently) receiving antiretroviral therapy 10. Number and percentage of pregnant women who know their HIV status results 11. Number of people tested for HIV, including the provision of results 12. Percentage of adults and children enrolled in HIV care who had TB status assessed and recorded during their last visit among all adults and children enrolled in HIV care in the reporting period 13. Number of STI cases treated

actual.comment: 1) 84.9%-For the cohort enrolled in the period 1 January 2013 – 31 December 2013, 511 PLHIV started receiving ART (290 men and 221 women). During the next 12 months 29 people died due to different reasons, 48 discontinued receiving treatment. 434 were recorded as PLHIV on treatment by the end of 12 months (234 men and 200 women). 2) 1111-PR conducted manual cross-check of all Unique Identification Codes (UIC), codes that received the services in more than one organization were counted only once. After excluding of repeated coded there have been 1111 PLHIV in total received various services as a minimum twice during the reported period (once during each quarter). 933 PLHIV (including 443 woman) out of them were reached by one PLHIV network and nine NGOs and 178 (including 6 woman) PLHIV received services at prisons through the Harm Reduction Network Association. 1,340 PLHIV as NGOs’ clients and prisoners received food packages in NGOs-3561 packages, SSES-473 packages. 11254-The activities under this indicator covered 5,254 clients of the governmental NSEPs and 6,392 NGO clients. After excluding duplicating codes, the total number of prevention programme’s clients is 11, 254 including 1,452 women. The number represents PWIDs who have received a minimal package, at least once during six months. According SR's reports NSEPs distributed 3,485.407 syringes, 457,520 condoms, 2.954,906 napkins. On average every PWID has been receiving 309 syringes, 40 condoms and 262 napkins in the reporting period. We have not excluded duplicate PWID codes between Chui and Bishkek totaling 189 clients(2,3% from total coverage of clients in Chui and Bishkek), as in 2012 study found that PWIDs generally received services in one specific area, and where there were duplicate codes in different geographic areas, this was a result of 2 PWIDs using the same UIC, rather than one UIC receiving services in two areas. 1344-There have been covered 1,344 prisoners who use injecting drugs (inclu
To be completed during the first half of 2016

indicator.title: Output Indicator

target.comment: 1. 33% of citizens and target groups are unsatisfied with the quality of 7 selected services provided to the citizens in 30 rural minucipalities 2. At least 40 % of citizens (esp. target groups) aware of their rights for access and provision of quality public and municipal services in 30 rural minucipalities 3. At least 35 of % citizens (esp. target groups) participate in local self-governance processes in 30 rural minucipalities (# of people involved in Women, Youth groups) 4. Increase the level of knowledge of the rights to access to Services in 10%.

actual.comment: Over the course of the project in 30 rural municipalities following achieved: 1. Average level of access to services increased from 44% in 2012 to 67% in 2014 – an improvement of 23 percentage points. 2. Average quality of services increased from 57% in 2012 to 75% in 2014 – an improvement of 18 percentage points. 3. The participation of women and youth in local decision making also increased from 46% in 2012 to 77% in 2014; 4. Average level of knowldge of target groups of their rights to access services increased from 26% in 2012 to 47% in 2014 among women and from 20% to 32% among youth respectively.

indicator.title: Output Indicator

target.comment: 1. Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; 2. TBD (Based on capacity needs assessment) 3. Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed 4. Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized 5. Built national capacity for donor coordination

actual.comment: 1. Coordination Platform for coordination of judicial reform is established among national partners (Zhogorku Kenesh, Government’s Office, President’s Office) and donor cluster. Provision of government’s updates on cofinancing proposals to the donor’s community in the Judicial reform process) 2. Re-scheduled for 2015 3. Re-scheduled for 2015 4. Methodology for conducting financial assessment of draft laws is drafted. It will be considered by the Parliament in 2015. 5. Secretariat of the Coordination Council will be established in 2015.

target.comment: 1.Recognized and formalized mechanism of cooperation of stakeholders on RoL for implementation issues; 2.TBD (Based on capacity needs assessment) 3. Training program and methodology on capacity building of key RoL institutions as part of the judicial reform implementation is developed 4. Methodology on financial assessments of Judicial Laws finalized 5. Built national capacity for donor coordination 6. At least ten CSOs are engaged in the Judicial reform process and their capacity is enhanced 7. Establishment of mechanism for civil society engagement in Rule of Law implementation reform process.
